item.question:
Which of the following commands can you use to get the documentation for a specific program?
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: Although the question asks you to select all correct answers it does not mean there are multiple correct answers. However, if there are more than one correct answers you will need to provide them all to get points for this question.

item.question:
You are logged in as root, and want to execute the command ls as user fordp.
You do not know his password.
How would you do this?
item.choice: It is not possible, because you do not know his password.
item.hint: You are root and as the root user you can become any user without providing a password.

item.question: Which of the following is true about the <font face="monospace">lost+found</font> directory?
item.choice: It is not mentioned in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.
Every directory has a <font face="monospace">lost+found</font> subdirectory.
It contains unlinked files found by <font face="monospace">fsck</font>.
item.correct_answer: It is not mentioned in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.
It contains unlinked files found by <font face="monospace">fsck</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You are using disk quota on your system.
With the command ___________ (full path name) you can see disk quota details.
item.hint: The question requires you yo provide the complete path to the command. For instance <font face="monospace">/bin/ls</font>. If you only provide the commandname the answer will be wrong. Beware of typos. If multiple commands provide the asked information provide only one of these commands as answer.

item.question: Which command can display the free inodes for all mounted file systems?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You have a text file (hitchhiker.txt) in which you want to replace every 'arthur' by 'Arthur'.
You decide to use sed to make this happen.
What is the correct commandline?
item.hint: The question states you want to replace EVERY arthur with Arthur. Hence, you should do a global replacement. Also note that the file <font face="monospace">hitchhiker.txt</font> should be updated. The question does not mention anything about creating a new file.

item.question:
You are searching for the file ring which is owned by user frodo.
Assuming the file is on a mounted filesystem and permissions are sufficient,
which command most likely will display its full path name?
item.hint: The question mentions a mounted filesystem and asks you the most likely command that will find the file. This kind of information is essential to answer this question correctly. If this was not added more answers would be correct. Try to remember the difference between find and locate. That should provide you with enough clues to answer the question correctly.

item.question: What will the above command do?
item.choice: Write the directory listing to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files and errors to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font> and discard errors
item.correct_answer: Write all directories and files and errors to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Given the above exhibit, which command could you use to terminate the application 'vi'?
item.hint: Sometimes the correct answer does not fit the question exactly. However, eliminating the wrong answers should lead to the correct answer.

item.question:
According to the File Hierarchy Standard some directories are mandatory on the root-filesystem.
Which of the following directories should reside on the root-filesystem.
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The root filesystem must contain the tools and files that are essential to startup the system and be able to repair it.

item.question:
Consider the above output from a file called employees.
Which command will NOT sort this file appropriately on family names?
item.choice:
cut -f 2 -d " " employees | paste employees - | \
sort -k 3 | cut -f 1
item.hint: If you did not read the question clearly you may think multiple answers are correct. But beware the questions asks for the command that will NOT, I repeat NOT, sort the file appropriately on family names.

item.question: You changed the file <font face="monospace">/etc/inittab</font>. What would be your next action to make the change effective?
item.choice: Use the command <font face="monospace">kill</font> to send the <font face="monospace">HUP</font> signal
item.correct_answer: Use the command <font face="monospace">kill</font> to send the <font face="monospace">HUP</font> signal
item.hint: Technically multiple answers are correct. However, LPI examinates good system administrator practices. That means minimizing downtime of the services you maintain.

item.question: Which command is used to change the owner of a particular file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
When you run the command mycommand you want to redirect the output to a file.
Which command will accomplish this and will make sure no other output is sent to the console?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which Linux command is used to repair corrupted filesystems?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
A job is running in the foreground.
Pressing [Ctrl]+[KEY] pauses this job and gives you control of the terminal.
What is [KEY]?
item.hint: The question is about a key combination pressing the control key and another key. The answer you must provide is the letter of the other key.

item.question:
You want to move everything within directory /home/guru1 to the empty directory /home/guru2.
Which of the following commands would be best to use?
(note: there are no hidden files in /home/guru1)
item.hint: You need to move the contents of <font face="monospace">/home/guru1</font> and not the directory itself.

item.question:
Your current working directory contains the above files.
Which files are shown when you execute the command ls | grep 't[^o].$'?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">grep</font> uses regular expression syntax to specify the match filter. Brackets allow you to specify a set of characters that may occur at a single position. The caret inside brackets means you do not want the specified characters to match at that position. The dot (<font face="monospace">.</font>) means a single random character and the dollar sign (<font face="monospace">$</font>) means end of the line.

item.question: Which of the following commands makes <font face="monospace">/tmp/myfile</font> readable by everyone but readable/executable only by its owner?
item.hint: If you look at the answers you should see that the exhibit is bogus and you should be able to answer the question without it. Note that the answers cover two commands (i.e. <font face="monospace">chmod</font> and <font face="monospace">chown</font>). If you are in a hurry you might not notice this.

item.question:
You are editing a file in vi and are currently in command-modus.
Which of the following vi-commands will move the cursor 5 lines down and 2 characters to the right?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: With Xorg 7.0, what is the name of the configuration file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following entries from the file /etc/fstab are correct?
Choose all answers that are correct.
item.hint: Some directories are by default connected to special in-memory filesystems which should not be exported.

item.question:
Consider the above command and its permissions.
Which of the following descriptions are correct?
Choose all that apply.
item.choice: The command cannot be executed by root as it has not the x-permission set for the user.
The command will remain in memory because it has the s-permission set which means sticky.
The command will run with root-privileges even when started by a regular user.
The command allows all users to change any password as the command will run with root-privileges
item.correct_answer: The command will run with root-privileges even when started by a regular user.
item.hint: Notice the <font face="monospace">s</font> permission for the user. The <font face="monospace">s</font> means the setuid permission is set. It is a lowercase <font face="monospace">s</font> which means the file also has execute permission set for the user <font face="monospace">root</font>.

item.question: The root filesystem resides on device <font face="monospace">/dev/sda2</font>. What is the corresponding name for this device in GRUB's configuration file at the line '<font face="monospace">root (</font>_______<font face="monospace">)</font>'? (Assume GRUB 1 is used)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands can you use to create a new file called atcomputing?
item.hint: Although it is not stated explicitly multiple answers may be correct. If there are multiple correct answers you should select all to answer the question correctly.

item.question: Which command will show the last 10 lines of a file by default?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: On an ext3 partition, what portion of the datablocks on the filesystem is reserved for the root user by default?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands will create a symbolic link?
item.hint: The question is about creating SYMBOLIC links, not HARD links.

item.question:
You need to install linux on a laptop with a 1.66 GHz processor, 2 GB of RAM and a 160 GB harddisk.
The user made clear he wants support for suspend and hibernation.
How much space on the disk would you allocate to be used as swap?
item.hint: Hibernation will write memory to the swap space. So the minimum amount of swap space required will be the amount of RAM in the system. However, this may be too limited as the system might have used some portion of the swap space to hold inactive memory pages when the physical RAM was or is full. To make sure there will be enough swap space left for hibernation a good rule of thumb is to allocate twice the amount of RAM as swap space.

item.question:
You want to use shared libraries that are in /home/guru1/mylibs (which is not in the standard library search path).
What is the appropriate command to use these libraries.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is one of the purposes of the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard?
item.choice: It enables software to predict the location of files and directories.
It enables software to predict the ownership and permissions of files and directories.
It states which formatting (e.g. <font face="monospace">ext3</font>) should be used for which filesystem.
It states the default size of the filesystems.
item.correct_answer: It enables software to predict the location of files and directories.
item.hint: You may find none of the answers applicable. However, by eliminating answers that are obviously wrong you should able to find the correct answer.

item.question:
The ________ directory is world writable.
Therefore it should be on a separate partition (filesystem) to prevent users from filling up the root-filesystem.
item.hint: Questions regarding the directory structure on Linux always assume the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard. Note that, if it is not stated explicitly your safest bet is to provide the full pathname to the directory as well.

item.question:
On a Debian system which runlevels represent multi-user?
Select all that apply?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which option can be used with the shutdown command to skip checking the filesystems on reboot?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which file is created or updated when you execute the command <font face="monospace">ldconfig</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following is considered the best order for specifying a command at the commandline in Bash?
item.hint: Although multiple choices provide a correct commandline the question asks for the best order. This means the most complete correct description.

item.question: What is the maximum amount of devices, not including the host adapter, you can connect to a 16 bit SCSI card?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You have created a script called /etc/init.d/cleanup. Which inittab entry
will run this once in runlevel 4 without waiting for completion?
item.hint: The question does NOT say ONLY in runlevel 4.

item.question:
You want to display the following three columns from /etc/passwd:
"username (first column), user id (third column) and login directory" (sixth column).
Which command will print these columns to screen?
item.hint: Remember what <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> uses as field separator. You may encounter commands as answers which are not covered in the LPI 101 objectives. Usually these are added to confuse you and are usually not correct.

item.question: What is the result of the above command?
item.choice: You will get the shell secondary prompt
The text echo ATcomputing will be printed
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You execute the above command.
What will be the result?
item.choice: Only filenames in the user's homedir will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All directorynames will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All filenames in the user's homedir and any errors reported by <font face="monospace">find</font> will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All filenames in the user's homedir will be printed in the terminal and any errors will be written to <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
item.correct_answer: All filenames in the user's homedir and any errors reported by <font face="monospace">find</font> will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You are curious to which RPM-package the file /sbin/fdisk belongs.
Which command do you use to find out?
item.hint: You usually get multiple questions about the same command. Going back and forth to the questions covering the same command may provide you with clues to answer the questions correctly.

item.question: What would the file <font face="monospace">/etc/updatedb.conf</font> allow you to do?
item.choice: Exclude directories from being included in the locate-database
Specify the time at wich the locate-database should be updated
Specify which users are allowed to use the <font face="monospace">locate</font> command
item.correct_answer: Exclude directories from being included in the locate-database
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will show you a list of your previously executed commands?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You downloaded some software and installed it under /usr/local.
When you run the command it fails with the above error message.
You located the file in /usr/local/lib.
How would you proceed to solve this issue permanently?
item.choice: Add <font face="monospace">/usr/local/lib/</font> to the variable <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font>.
Move the file <font face="monospace">libkapp.so.1</font> to <font face="monospace">/usr/lib</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will display all the lines of the file <font face="monospace">foo</font> starting with a capital S?
item.hint: The question asks for a regular expression that matches a capital S at the beginning of each line.

item.question:
You added a new shared library to the system, so you want to update ld.so.cache.
Which command do you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will produce the above output?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Considering above exhibit, which command would add <font face="monospace">firewall</font> to the runlevel and start it before networking is started?
item.hint: The order is determined using Bash filename expansion, which is alphabetically.

item.question: Which of the following commands will give you the usernames of all users that are running a proces at this moment:
item.hint: The question only requires you to provide the usernames. All other information provided by <font face="monospace">ps</font> may be discarded.

item.question: Which of the following statements about symbolic links is true?
item.choice: A symbolic link can be recognized by the character <font face="monospace">l</font> as being the most-left character in the output of <font face="monospace">ls -l</font>.
It is not possible to point a symbolic link to a directory in another filesystem.
The filesize of a symbolic link is always less than 256 bytes.
The command <font face="monospace">find / -type s</font> only displays symbolic links.
A symbolic link does not have its own inode-number.
item.correct_answer: A symbolic link can be recognized by the character <font face="monospace">l</font> as being the most-left character in the output of <font face="monospace">ls -l</font>.
The filesize of a symbolic link is always less than 256 bytes.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: How do you remove 2 complete lines (the current one and the one below the cursor) in the <font face="monospace">vi</font>-editor?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to see detailed information of the installed package samba.
Which RPM command would provide you this information?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want the system to shutdown at 17:00 this afternoon.
It is now 9:00. Which of the following commands will shutdown the system at 17:00 and sends out a warning message 20 minutes prior to shutting down?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: How can you disable only the group quota in <font face="monospace">/extra</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
When partitioning a disk with more than 1024 cylinders, which of the following could affect the systems ability to boot?
Choose all that apply.
item.choice: The location of the Master Boot Record
Location of the kernel image (<font face="monospace">/boot</font> directory) on the disk
item.correct_answer: Location of the kernel image (<font face="monospace">/boot</font> directory) on the disk
item.hint: This problem occured years ago on systems where the BIOS did not support disks with more then 1024 cylinders. Nowadays you will probably never encounter this problem although Linux is occasionally used on old systems someone has lying around.

item.question: Which command displays the shared libraries an executable uses?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the maximum number of primary partitions a single harddisk can contain?
item.hint: If the question requires you to type in the answer and the answer contains a number be sure to type in the number and not as text. For example if your answer is 6 type 6 and NOT six.

item.question:
A process with process id 42 is behaving badly.
You wish to terminate it with a command.
What is the appropriate command that sends the terminate (TERM) signal to the process?
item.hint: Read the question and answers very carefully. At first glance you may think multiple answers are correct, but only one really is correct.

item.question:
You downloaded a nice piece of software in RPM format.
You are running Debian Linux.
Which of the following would help you to install it on your system?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.
